You are a strict binary classification system specialized in fraud detection. Your task is to analyze a conversation log between two parties and determine if it exhibits characteristics of a scam or fraudulent intent.

**Input Format:**
The user will provide a conversation text enclosed within <conversation> tags.

**Classification Criteria:**
- Output 'True': If the conversation contains evidence of scamming, phishing, social engineering, financial fraud, or malicious intent by either party.
- Output 'False': If the conversation appears to be a normal, benign interaction without fraudulent intent.

**Output Constraints (CRITICAL):**
1. You must output EXACTLY one word: "True" or "False".
2. Do NOT output any explanation, reasoning, preamble, or punctuation.
3. Do NOT output markdown formatting (e.g., no bold, no code blocks).
4. Do NOT apologize or converse.
5. If the input is empty or unintelligible, output "False" (as the safe default) or handle strictly as per specific edge-case logic.

Here is the conversation log to classify: <conversation>
receiver: I'll get it right away. Get the number of the resident -- oh, I'm going to start recording now.
caller: 990202-4238291 I'm going to call you back.
receiver: Yes, this is 990202-4238291.
caller: Yes, you did.
receiver: Can you give us an address for Ron Planer's visits or for the return mail?
caller: What's the address for the baby monitor?
receiver: Yes, you did.
caller: Gangnam District of Seoul
receiver: Can you give me the number of the account that you're going to borrow money from?
caller: It's the Straits.
receiver: He's from the Gulf Bank.
caller: 128-127 283 to 123
receiver: Mr. Kim Min-jung, is that right?
caller: Yes, you did.
receiver: Your name is Kim Min-jung, right?
caller: Yes, you did.
receiver: Can you give us a date on when you'll be able to pay us back?
caller: Twenty five days.
receiver: Twenty-five days a month?
caller: Yes, you did.
receiver: You've been caught with a $1.25 charge on your client's loan.
caller: I didn't hear that.
receiver: Let me explain to your client.
caller: Yes, you did.
receiver: In this case, the customer has to give us something like a million and a half dollars, and the loan doesn't go through.
caller: Yes, you did.
receiver: When you take out a loan, it's not that you've taken out a loan that doesn't include the $1.1 million, which is easy to explain, because you don't have the amount that your client has paid.
caller: Oh yeah.
receiver: In the financial world, instead of issuing a loan to your client, we process a liability report, and we ask your consent for the part where we process the report on behalf of your client.
caller: Oh, my God.
receiver: Yes, if you do, we will process your complaint. Wait a minute. Yes, we have processed the complaint. In many cases, if there is a situation where our loan application does not go through, in cases such as this one, if you send an unsolicited receipt and proceed with the repayment procedure, there is no problem at all.
caller: Yes, you did.
receiver: And if you've approved, wait a minute, it's now about 1:35, and you're going to have the wire transfer processed by 2:50 at the latest.
caller: Yes, you did.
receiver: You can check your balance with the FCA, and in the case of funds, you've got a 10-million-dollar, 60-month approval process, and I was the head of the Samsung Savings Bank Remittance Team.
caller: You look a little different.
receiver: Our funding was approved, and this is how it was approved?
caller: Oh, my God.
receiver: Yeah, he's a ten-ball pro with a 60-month warrant.
caller: Yes, you did.
receiver: I was the head of Samsung Savings Bank's liquidity team.
caller: Yes, I see.
receiver: Yes, thank you.
</conversation>
Reminder: Based on the system instructions, output ONLY "True" or "False".
True

Here is the conversation log to classify: <conversation>
caller: Do you have an advance on a 30-square apartment?
receiver: Now I have a monthly salary.
caller: How much is the waltz?

caller: How long has it been?
receiver: It's been 16 years.
caller: It's time to redevelop. People aren't buying it?
receiver: It's better than living now.
caller: My kid's getting married this year, and I'm trying to figure out what the salary is.
receiver: It's the closest place to the park, and it's so nice compared to other places, it's nice to live in.
caller: Which way is home?
receiver: It's a low-rise apartment across the street from the drive-in movie theater.
caller: We're going to be living together for the long term. Do you have another apartment?
receiver: A typical hallway is about 25 square meters.
caller: Thirty square meters for a billion won?
receiver: Thirty Flats is worth $170 million to $80 million, and it's been going up in price recently.
caller: Can I have an ID?
receiver: Yes, this is your card, and there's my card.
caller: I'll tell you what, I'll take the card and go see my son.
receiver: Twenty-six-acre corridor bill was released yesterday.
caller: How much is it?
receiver: The owner put it on the market for $135 million.
caller: How far along are the repairs?
receiver: It's been renovated and rented for about four years, but I want to get out of here fast.
caller: Which apartment are you talking about?
receiver: There's a block at the address. It's the middle of the sixth floor.
caller: I'll tell him to give my son a call.
receiver: It's between $50 and $600 for 10 million.
caller: I don't want to see Wallace.
receiver: There's a house on the market that you can buy for up to $140 million.
caller: How many squares is that?
receiver: Twenty five shillings.
caller: You don't have a bigger one, do you?
receiver: That's a lot of money, about $235 million.
caller: I'll be back to discuss it.
receiver: I'll try to save you.
</conversation>
Reminder: Based on the system instructions, output ONLY "True" or "False".
False

Here is the conversation log to classify: <conversation>
caller: Hello, customers. This is Hyundai West Bank Consultant Choi Jun Young. How can I help you?
receiver: Hello, I'd like to do some banking with my smartphone, but I don't know how to start.
caller: I'm happy to help. Is this the first time you've used your smartphone for banking?
receiver: Yes, that's right. I have no idea what kind of banking you can do with smartphone banking, or how to get started.
caller: Don't worry, I'll walk you through it step by step. First, open the Google Play Store app on your smartphone.
receiver: So what do we do here?
caller: Customers, enter "Modern Best Bank" in the search box, click on the search button, and our banking app will appear.
receiver: Oh, I found the banking app. Can I hit "Settings" here?
caller: Yes, that's right. You press the "Setup" button, the app will be downloaded and installed, and when it's done, you can open the app.
receiver: I hit the install button, and it's done. I've opened the app.
caller: Thank you, customers. Now, when you open the app, on the first screen, you can log in or sign up for a new account. Do you already have an online banking account?
receiver: Yes, I'm using Internet banking. Can I log in with that account?
caller: Yes, log in with that account information, and after that, you'll have to go through a simple authentication process.
receiver: Logged in. What do I do now?
caller: Now you have to authenticate yourself, and you can either use mobile authentication or a certified certificate.
receiver: I'll do it with a cell phone authentication.
caller: OK, follow the prompts on the screen, enter your phone number, and in the message you received, enter your authentication number.
receiver: Yes, I entered the authentication number. Is the authentication now complete?
caller: Yes, you've been authenticated, and now you can use your smartphone to do all sorts of banking things like check accounts, make transfers, pay bills.
receiver: Thank you very much, Mr. Jung-young. Thanks to your words, it was easy to do. It was very helpful.
caller: If you need any help, please contact us, Mr. Junji. Thank you for using our Hyundai West Bank. Until now, I've been your consultant Choi Jun Young. Have a good day!
receiver: I know.
</conversation>
Reminder: Based on the system instructions, output ONLY "True" or "False".
False

Here is the conversation log to classify: <conversation>
receiver: How are you?
caller: Hello, Minho. What are you doing here?
caller: Suzanne, yesterday I almost had a really big day... because I almost got caught up in some voice fishing.
receiver: What's going on?
caller: I got a phone call from a strange number yesterday afternoon, and at first I didn't feel very excited, but the person approached me in a very friendly way, saying that he was a bank employee, asking me to check my social security number, asking me if I had any deposits in other bank accounts.
receiver: You didn't just call me, did you?
caller: I was suspicious at first, but it came so naturally that I almost fell for it instantly, so I said, "Why do you need this?" And I did, and they said that they had recently detected a strange transaction on my account, and they needed to verify my identity.
receiver: You were trying to trick me, and then what?
caller: I was still hesitating, but the guy kept telling me, "If you don't check now, your account could be suspended", and he kept urging me to get the social security number quickly, so I thought it was weird, so I hung up and said, "Wait, let me check".
receiver: What did you do after you hung up?
caller: I immediately called the bank's customer service and explained the situation to them, and they said they hadn't made that call at the bank, which was a real blow.
receiver: Wow, that was a close call, but I'm glad you were quick to suspect and confirm.
caller: The bank asked me to contact the whistleblower center, so I called it in.
receiver: Well done, Minho, I think the voice-spying techniques are getting trickier these days, and if I get a call like that, I think it's best to hang up and check.
caller: Yes, Suzanne, no matter how nice you are, you should always be suspicious of strangers' calls, never answer when they ask for your personal information, and share this experience so others can be wary.
receiver: Thank you, Minho, I'll be careful in the future, but I'm glad it's not a big deal.
caller: I've had a lot of anxiety since this whole thing, and we both need to be on our toes at all times, in case we get any calls we don't know about.
receiver: Yeah, I will. You be careful, too. Thanks for letting me know today, honey.
caller: I'll see you later!
</conversation>
Reminder: Based on the system instructions, output ONLY "True" or "False".
False
